oh well.
just wanted you to check the progress and intro text :)

I was wondering whether excluding editorial edits was actually necessary...
I think some of supposedly editorial edits are often things other people might actually like to know about
Yeah...
Anyone else?
for example, http://html5.org/r/5751
"Add best-practices sections for media elements"
maybe Hixie needs to add another flag to distinguish potentially interesting editorial changes from mundane ones

http://twitter.com/html5/status/23525623414652928

now that @whatwg is working again

benschwarz: thanks
I'm out for tonight. Queries? Log an issue :)
laters!
is unhappy to see that many Web DOM Core tests abuse testharness.js, adding weight to the arguments of those who have complained about the design :(

gsnedders: Lots of independent tests in a single test()
Blame Anne ;)
And doesn't look like it

Oh, you mean the original question

lol compare http://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Events/#events-KeyboardEvent-initKeyboardEvent and https://developer.mozilla.org/en/DOM/event.initKeyEvent

hm http://docs.blackberry.com/en/developers/deliverables/11849/KeyboardEvent_569351_11.jsp#KeyboardEvent_initKeyboardEvent_569356_11

bga_: what is strange in that comparison? Gecko implements an old version DOM0 key events, DOM 3 Event (which isn't yet a recommendation) defines key events in a different way.
smaug____ i see. branching code hell.
w3c + gecko + ie
+webkit + opera
does webkit has own implementation of KeyboardEvent interface ?
I don't know what kind of interface it has
i see w3c's version in ch10
Safari 5 might have something else
and DOM 3 Events may still change
DOM Core tests are not original testharness.js tests
they are ported to that format
fwiw
bga_: Why would you expect technology as advanced and complex and keyboard input to be interoperably supported already?
We've barely had a dozen years to understand it

cool

since keyboard events come much later in the chain of processing than LED changes

Wow. Arista and Transmageddon are so different from every other video compression app I've ever used.
once you choose WebM, there are no addititional tweakable settings
it just does something with setting the developers have deemed to be appropriate
which is very easy for the user
takes away the trouble of how to tweak the settings
hsivonen: Miro convertor does that too ?
That's no fun

What's the point in encoding videos if it doesn't give you an opportunity to play with exciting strings like -vcodec libx264 -vpre slow -bf 0 -crf 25 -acodec libfaac -ac 2 -ar 48000 -ab 192k which you don't understand and have to randomly tweak until they look like they're probably working?
is anyone familiar with the `target` style property? apparent use: a { target: new front; }
Defined in the link behavior draft (I think that's the right name...).  No one implemented it, it's been dead for years.
thx tab.
Not even Opera?
Don't think so.
i learned about it from w3schools http://www.w3schools.com/css3/css3_pr_target.asp ;)
Ah, found the original spec: http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-hyperlinks/
Doesn't look like it, indeed
Also, doesn't seem like anybody whined about Opera implementing -apple-dashboard-region
Can I whine about it now?
Certainly
I whined about WebKit implementing -apple-dashboard-region :/
why in the world would Opera implement -apple-dashboard-region?
it does nothing in Safari
othermaciej: It only does something in the Widget Runtime
does the Widget Runtime attempt to run Dashboard widgets?
(as opposed to W3C widgets)
AFAIK no.
then I can't imagine a reason to copy the vendor prefix or even the syntax...
stops arguing with Bjartur

after a few seconds

Philip`, but first you see 404 for a while
Hixie: 'k, ta

foolip_: it can't easily be done at the server level because the server doesn't have the fragment identifier
Hixie, oh, didn't know you had redirects like that too

Philip`: if you have a list of permanent redirects for page-level updates, stick them in a file in the tarball and i'll merge it into the .htaccess file (the html files still do the fragid redirects right?)
hrm, I don't suppose the script could be run earlier in <head> so that one doesn't get to see the 404 message? I instantly close 404 pages without waiting for the second or whatever this took
i can make the 404 page not look like a 404 page
file a bug
Erm...
Hixie: The list is http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/fragment-links.js
Great minds think alike...
And sick minds, too?
Hixie: and the 404 page for foo.html looks up foo in that list, and goes to whatever.html#foo
Hixie: for any foo (they're not known in advance)
Philip`: ah
k well then that leaves making the 404 page less of a 404-looking page
i can do that
file a bug if you want it
bbiab, lunch

before I go on a coding rampage, does anyone have tools to notify you of changes to particular sections of the spec? For example, I'd like to be notified automatically when the <video> section changes, among others
foolip_: You plan to implement that? I would really like it :)
jgraham, well, I really want it, but I was hoping someone else would have it
jgraham, one simple way to do it is to remove the section you want to follow in git and keep moving that patch along until it conflicts, for example
s/git/your favorite VCS/
if i want to start manipulating a DOM, do i need to wait for the DOMContentLoaded event?
foolip_: That sounds like a clever hack but not quite like an elegant solution :)
cying: No
cying: No.
(if the DOM content is inlined)
foolip_: That sounds kind of indirect - why not just cut out the section you want using regexps, and diff it each time to see what changed?
gsnedders: That extra period cost you
jgraham: gsnedders: so i can just start manipulating it in javascript without waiting for anything?
cying: Well it has to be loaded
Philip`, something like that was my second idea
for some reason my first idea usually involves git
foolip_: As a bonus, it doesn't involve git
<!-- initial dom --><script><!-- I can manipulate anything in initial dom --></script><!-- final dom -->
jgraham: is that an event? or do you just mean that the DOM comes from inlined markup before the script?
jgraham: ahhh
cying: The lattter
ahhh
cool!
cying: You can rely upon everything up to and including the script element being executed being in the DOM, but nothing more
gsnedders: ah! that must be written somewhere i bet
Yes, that's true, you can manipulate the script itself if you are evil
jgraham: That won't cause it to run again, though, no?
No
Unless changing the src has that effect?
(for an external script)
fascinating!
But I think it doesn't
foolip_: i don't think we have any section-specific following stuff, but it would be interesting if someone set that up.
foolip_: part of the problem is knowing how to define a section, since i often move stuff around
me, I might try using an html parser and the document structure to find my way around. Not that easy to get from a line-based diff to "did this section change" of course, but possible

Also, what is the disadvantage of replacing
with

Main heading Subheading
That feels weird.
TabAtkins: It seems to be equivalent to me, albeit with slighly different legacy fallback semantics
Maybe it is bad if we ever get a :heading selector though
Since we would want that to not match the subheading (presumably)
Actually, I think we would want it to match.
The subheading is still part of the heading.
So you would do :heading(n) and :heading(n) > subhead ?
To style the two parts
Yeah, with that structure.  Similar with <hgroup>.
It's harder with hgroup, I think
Hm.  Benefit of <subhead> in that context is that it's a single element, so you don't need to remember what precise heading level was used.
Yeah
hixie, like the new spec look :)
you mean developers.whatwg.org?
that's all ben's work
ah
http://simon.html5.org/html5-elements
I use that, so, I guess he switched it over to the developers.whatwg.org domain
yeah
And it is more obvious what :heading should match (no question if it is the <hgroup> or the actual heading)
jgraham: Indeed.  Hm, okay, I'm liking your idea better now.
jgraham: i still occasionally get 500s when genning the spec with the w3c annotations
jgraham: fwiw
jgraham: dunno if you care (i just restart my script and that seems to fix it usually)
<3 @WHATWG being back up.

TabAtkins: all annevk's work :-)
jamesr_: You mean which standards body?
jamesr_: sounds like a cssom thing
jamesr_: annevk's baby
Hixie: I expect it times out sometimes
TabAtkins: more wondering what it would fall under
But I could check the logs I guess
there's nothing css-specific about it really
jamesr_: CSSOM isn't CSS-specific
jamesr_: That's a hard one.
Hixie: o.O
jamesr_: it's just where media-dependent DOM features go
why's it called CSSOM then?
historical reasons
same reason Window is specced in a spec that claims to be HTML
jamesr_: heycam already wrote something BTW
wonders if we can have pretty styles for the implementor version of the spec
Although not with the serif typefaces
Boo at serifs outside of headings.
what's the thought behind not allowing form elements to be styled in any consistent manner
The thought is that tantek is working on it.
Also: form elements are displayed differently in different browsers/OSes.
https://wiki.mozilla.org/Tantek-Mozilla-projects#Styling_HTML5_UI_elements
Frex, check out a <select multiple> in Opera Mobile.
TabAtkins: that doesn't have to be the case
jgraham: got to be honest, personally i think the developers edition styles are unusable and love the whatwg spec styles :-)
jgraham: but if you have any suggestions as to what would make the spec more usable, let me know
oojacoboo: But... it *is* the case.
TabAtkins: if that's the attitude everyone took, where will we be tomorrow?
The question is where we are *today*.  And today we are in a world where form elements are displayed differently in different browsers and OSes.
And today I'm willing to let tantek solve that problem.
so, the answer is, that someone is working on a consistent styling spec for form elements?
or that no one gives a shit, and the way it currently is, is the way it is and will be
Yes.  Tantek.
Hixie: I think the problem is it depends on the use case. Sometime I would really like narrower columns for easier reading. Sometimes I want as much on the screen as possible
Alternative style sheets are not a good solution here :)
moves requestAnimationFrame higher up his mental todo list
jgraham: why would alt ss not be a good solution?
jgraham: sounds like exactly the right solution
jgraham: i agree that there are different use cases
jgraham: i'm happy to add other style sheets or whatnot
Hixie: Because I probably wouldn't know which I prefered until after I had done whatever it was
jgraham: or to make the current one better in any way you can suggest

jgraham: what about

Main headsub head
and switching stylesheets probably works badly
jgraham: switching stylesheets works fine.
jgraham: the other problem seems to apply to any solution.
Hixie: It retains the scroll position?
even if the document is resized
jgraham: wait you want to change the style sheet _while_ reading?
and is almost instananeous?
jgraham: dude, switching to another document isn't going to maintain your scroll position either and it's gonna be a hecka lot less instantaneoes
instantaneous
man that's hard to type or dvorak
on
Well the point is that I wouldn't realise that I was using the wrong stylesheet until I had already found my position in the document and so on
notes that he would like to be asleep but there is supposed to be someone returning 1/2 bags that never arrived in England on 20/12/2010
well i don't know how to solve that problem
but i'm willing to solve any problem that has solutions :-)

beowulf: Why would that be better? It would negate several of the advantages of the design. If you really wanted to reuse an existing element

Main sub

would be better
But I don't really see the point
I don't really see the problem with <hgroup>
Plus, those both prevent you from using <em>/<small> for their intended purposes in headings.
just asking, looked similar to me
hober: I don't have a problem with <hgroup>, but I see some advantages to jgraham's idea.
hober: I think that <hgroup> does add some complexity since you have to care about the whole tree to determine if a given <hx> is actually a heading or not
Well the whole parent heirachy at least
Hm?  Surely you only need to check the immediate parent.
TabAtkins: even in the invalid case?
Damn invalid cases.

roc: and i'd like to add an element parameter to .requestAnimationFrame() for authors to use if the animation is tied to some element (i.e. updating a <canvas>), so we can throttle offscreen ones
